titleStmt.title: Commonwealth of Kentucky v. Whittaker et al., Transcript
CWG10888

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Beriah Magoffin: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons and Remissions, 1859-1862

body.p:
Commonwealth of Kentucky
Shelby County } sct
To any any Constable of Shelby County Greeting

You are Commanded to Summons, L. B. Whittaker C. D. Cooper & William Whittaker to appear before me or Some other Justice of the peace for Shelby County September the 11th 1861 to answer for having comitted a breach of the peace on Sept 4th 1861, by fighting throwing stones hammers &c you are also commanded to summons Joseph Earley J. D. Baker Samuel Dowdy Witnesses for plantiffs summons a good & lawfull Jury to by the above case Given under my as Justice of the peace for Shelby county this 5to day of ASeptember 1861
J. H. McCampbell J. P. C.
The following is the endorsement of the Constable executed by ready the with to C. D Cooper L. B. Whittaker & William Whittaker Sept 4th 1861
Jno F Moore C. S. C.
The following is the pannel of the Jury. To wit Washington Gowen C. T. Sheppard R. Sample Wash Lisby Jeff Lisby W. B. Reaid E. Owen J Burnet J M Hedden S. Dowdy G. Washby Jas W. Baker.
The following is Verdict of the Jury, We of the Jury find L. B. Whittaker twenty seven dollars & 50 cents & cost. C. D. Cooper & William Whittaker not guilty
State of Kentucky Shelby County Sct } Washington Gowen foreman
I do certify that the above is a true and perfect record of the proceeding had before me, on the 11th day of September 1861
J. H. McCampbell J. P. S. C

To his Excellency Gov B. Magoffin I can state that Mr L. B. Whittaker is a peacible Citizen of the County, and was in his shop at the time the affray commenced, and is a poor man with a large family this 16th Sept 1861
J. H. McCampbell J. P. S. C

Comth Ky
vs } Copy
Whittaker at others
